conclusion: Determine the distance traveled by the car over 60 seconds based on the acceleration-time graph.
The graph shows acceleration as a function of time.
From t = 0 to t = 20 seconds, the acceleration is 2 m/s^2.
From t = 20 to t = 40 seconds, the acceleration is 0 m/s^2.
From t = 40 to t = 60 seconds, the acceleration is -1 m/s^2.
Calculate velocity and position for each segment and sum them to find total distance.
Velocity at t = 20 seconds is 40 m/s using integral of acceleration.
Velocity at t = 40 seconds is 40 m/s using integral of acceleration.
Velocity at t = 60 seconds is -20 m/s using integral of acceleration.
Distance for first segment (0 to 20 seconds) is 400 m using integral of velocity.
Distance for second segment (20 to 40 seconds) is 800 m using integral of velocity.
Distance for third segment (40 to 60 seconds) is calculated using integral of velocity.
